Building Network Servers

Zilogic Systems

TCP Servers

TCP Server Operations

  • In a TCP client, after a socket is created the client tries to connect to a server.
  • But a TCP server, listens on a socket and waits for a connection.
  • The TCP server must wait on a known/standard port.
  • When a connection comes in and the TCP server accepts the connection, a new socket is created which is connected to the client.
  • The server can continue to listen for more requests in the socket associated with the standard port.
  • Running a TCP server involves 3 steps, after socket creation.
    1. Associate the socket with a standard port.
    2. Inform the network layer that this is a server socket.
    3. Accept each incoming connection request.

Associating to Standard Port

  • The socket can be associated with a specific port no. using the bind() system call. 
#include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>

ret = bind(sockfd, (struct sockaddr *)&myaddr, sizeof(myaddr));

int sockfd;
struct sockaddr_in myaddr;
int ret;
  • sockfd is the socket that is to be bound to the specified port.
  • myaddr specifies the port no. The IP address part is set to the macro IPADDR_ANY.
  • On error bind() returns -1 and sets errno accordingly.
  • Ports less than 1024, are standard ports and only processes with superuser privileges can bind to those ports. If a non-superuser process tries to bind to those ports bind, returns with an error.

Accepting Connections

Converting to a Server Socket

  • To notify the network layer that we would like to listen on the socket for incoming connection requests, the listen() syscall can be used. 
#include <sys/socket.h>

ret = listen(sockfd, backlog)

int sock_fd;
int backlog;
int ret;
  • sockfd is the socket that has to be converted to a server socket.
  • backlog is the maximum no. of pending connection requests.
  • On error listen() returns -1 and sets errno accordingly.

Accepting Incoming Connections

#include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>

newfd = accept(sockfd, (struct sockaddr *)client_addr, &len)

int sockfd;
struct sockaddr_in client_addr;
int len;
int newfd;
  • sockfd is the server socket from which we would like to accept connections.
  • client_addr is the socket address of the client that has connected to the server.
  • len specifies the size of the address structure passed. The syscall modifies len to the actual sizeof the structure returned. In case of IP, both the passed structure and returned structure size are the same.
  • accept() returns the newly created socket fd, through which the client can be contacted.
  • accept() returns -1 if error occured and sets errno accordingly.

Web Server

  • The 1.1 version of the HTTP protcol, the basic GET request and response is as follows. 
C GET /index.html HTTP/1.1 <1>
C Host: www.zilogic.com <2>
S HTTP/1.1 200 OK <3>
S Content-Type: text/html <4>
S <5>
S <index.html file contents>

  1. This is the GET request from the client. It has the request name, the file, HTTP protocol version.

  2. The client specifies the host it is contacting.

  3. The status line from the servers. It has the HTTP protocol version, status code, and message. 200 is success.

  4. The server then specifies the content type. Whether it is jpeg image, plain text or HTML file.

  5. Blank line, followed by file contents.

Hello Web Server

#include <sys/types.h>
#include <sys/socket.h>
#include <sys/stat.h>
#include <fcntl.h>
#include <unistd.h>

#include <netinet/in.h>
#include <netinet/ip.h>

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <errno.h>
#include <error.h>

void handle_http(int sock_fd)
{
        char *resp = \
                "HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\n"
                "Content-Type: text/html\r\n"

2 6 4 12 5 20 1 5 1 10 2 17 0 6 1 10 1 13 1 3 1 7 2 12 1 4 2 8 4 11 2 4 4 8 7 12 3 5 7 10 11 16 9 10 16 21 20 32 5 10 8 23 8 36.9 0 6.9-1 13.6-3 20.1 2 0 3 .8 4 2.2s2 4.4 3 9.1l1 7.4c1 2.2 2 4.3 5 6.1 2.7l-7-.8c-8-2.1-13-6.1-16-12.2-16-1.94-29-2.9-37-2.9\"/>"
                "</svg>"
                "</body>"
                "</html>";

        char req[1024];
        int ret;

        ret = read(sock_fd, req, sizeof(req));
        if (ret == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error reading HTTP request");

        printf("%s\n", req);

        ret = write(sock_fd, resp, strlen(resp));
        if (ret == -1 || ret != strlen(resp))
                error(1, errno, "error writing HTTP response");
}

int main()
{
        int listen_fd;
        int sock_fd;
        int ret;

        struct sockaddr_in myaddr;
        struct sockaddr_in client_addr;

        listen_fd = socket(PF_INET, SOCK_STREAM, 0);
        if (listen_fd == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error creating socket");

        myaddr.sin_family = AF_INET;
        myaddr.sin_port = htons(8085);
        myaddr.sin_addr.s_addr = htonl(INADDR_ANY);

        ret = bind(listen_fd, (struct sockaddr *) &myaddr, sizeof(myaddr));
        if (ret == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error binding to port 8085");

        ret = listen(listen_fd, 10);
        if (ret == -1)
                error(1, errno, "error listening on socket");

        while (1) {
                pid_t pid;
                socklen_t len;

                len = sizeof(client_addr);
                sock_fd = accept(listen_fd,
                                 (struct sockaddr *)
                                 &client_addr, &len);
                if (sock_fd == -1)
                        error(1, errno,
                              "error accepting connections");

                handle_http(sock_fd);
        }
}
